text: <@U012M1K3PKM> No problem Christian. That's right, yep. It's a bit of a gap in HubSpot's APIs at the moment, hence the suggested workaround. At the moment, currency exchange rates must be set manually within the web UI, and I'm not aware of any API endpoint that gives you exchange rates set within the given portal. Somewhat related to this community idea thread: <https://community.HubSpot.com/t5/HubSpot-Ideas/Feature-request-Auto-update-currency-conversion-rates/idc-p/413222#M75719>
Thx <@U010M6T8DEW>
Happy to help :slightly_smiling_face: <@U012M1K3PKM>

Is it intended the domain part of an email gets punycoded ?
I've encountered some issues, where emails i add through the api, can't be found, and it turns out it's because the api silently punycodes the domain.
Example: adding køvtester@køvtest.com becomes kø<mailto:vtester@xn--kvtest-bya.com|vtester@xn--kvtest-bya.com>.

It handles special characters fine in front of the @ but not after.

I have created deal in HubSpot with company associated to it.

When we fetch the data through API the company ID associated to the deal coming as `null` .

Company details:

```{
            "id": "5229468596",
            "properties": {
                "company_id": null,
                "createdate": "2021-05-11T15:04:09.995Z",
                "hs_lastmodifieddate": "2021-05-11T15:05:21.567Z",
                "hs_object_id": "5229468596"
            },
            "createdAt": "2021-05-11T15:04:09.995Z",
            "updatedAt": "2021-05-11T15:05:21.567Z",
            "archived": false
        }```
API i Hit:

```<https://api.hubapi.com/crm/v3/objects/deals?limit=100&properties=company_id>```
Any  insights?
Hi <@U021FM2AYN9>, dang, that's my theory shattered then. Definitely exactly the same endpoint and hapikey used Postman vs. cURL?

<@U021FM2AYN9> one good way to debug issues like this is to put an interceptor between your code and the HubSpot API.  This way you can see the complete request payload the your code is sending, and the complete response payload the HubSpot is sending back.  That should make it very clear whether the data is in the response or not... if it is, then the problem is with your code that is receiving/parsing/displaying it; if not then you probably want to carefully compare the request your code is sending vs. what Postman is sending.

I'm partial to Beeceptor for this kind of debugging, but there are probably lots of similar services out there.  Take a look at <https://docs.beeceptor.com/docs/features-inspect-requests/> to get started.
The HubSpot API documentation has a see all extra params
click on that gives you a extra option called associations you want that one in your query string
Good idea <@U01BBV0L2CF> I like <https://webhook.site/> for this kind of thing too :thumbsup:

Anyone know why the same call is now giving error 400 "Bad Request"? I was able to successfully hit the endpoint <https://api.hubapi.com/crm/v3/objects/deals/batch/update> about 5 minutes ago and now the same call is erroring out.
Check out this endpoint, if all you are doing is getting associations: <https://legacydocs.HubSpot.com/docs/methods/crm-associations/get-associations>
try with this endpoint specfically: <https://api.hubapi.com/crm-associations/v1/associations/XXXX_YOUR_DEAL_ID_XXXX/HubSpot_DEFINED/5?hapikey=demo>
and if that doesn't work for you try replacing the 5 with a 6 at the end of the URL
You might have a bad / malformed update in the batch. The error message should tell you which one is giving you the problem/
